Fields.DialogueText: You wanted to see me about something?
Join me up on the bridge for a minute.
Une minute?
Too long for you to stand about?
So, Capitaine, What is on your mind?

Fields.MenuText: I just wanted to share a pleasant breeze. The winds usually aren't this kind to us.
I just wanted to ask how you're doing. You were down there with the boilers for hours.
I just wanted to know what you thought about our patrol so far.

Fields.DialogueText: C'est une belle journe. You like the simple things, non?
That's very kind, Capitaine. There wasn't anything alarming going on, though - the stress testing went as expected.
A bit boring lately, but it's nice not having Command bother us so much.
I just hope things keep going this well. A few more days without a Morgana sighting would feel like a proper vacation.
Oui. That would be nice.
I suppose you could say that.
Definitely better than many alternatives. Okay.
Not for you. Allow me to dispatch the incoming Morganas and I'll be right with you.
@BATTLE
I need that transmission decoded faster, Lieutenant.
The radio room is nearly finished, Capitaine.
So you keep saying. It's taken over an hour to break a priority message from Command.
Our radio room is working as fast as they can.
Maybe something has changed, but the last time I checked, this was a warship. We should be somewhat more proficient at this sort of thing.
Oui. Bien sûr.
Thanks for that, Maillé Brézé.
Ce n'est rien, Capitaine.
... If you keep tapping your foot like that on my deck, you will find it perfectly sturdy.
And that will be the only thing I've accomplished since I got here. Do either of you have any idea why this is taking so long?
I will find out, Capitaine.
Command is counting on us to decode priority messages promptly.

Fields.MenuText: We have to be faster.
I'll try to be patient. The message's accuracy is what really counts.
Give me the codebooks. If they can't get the job done, I'll do it myself.

Fields.DialogueText: Faster is always better! I agree. Wasting time in war is unacceptable.
You are not punishing them for their laziness?
Trs impulsif, Capitaine. Are you sure you even know how to use the codebooks?
*ALARM*
Morganas? Good, I was getting bored from all this waiting around. Off I go!
Damn it, Maillé Brézé, wait for me!
@BATTLE
*sigh* Maillé Brézé.
I was expecting more action from you, Capitaine.
Feels like the winds just shifted...
Bonjour, Capitaine.
Was the weather report in error?
Non, Capitaine. We just changed our course to the east.
But I didn't order a course change.
Haha! Non, mon petit chou, I did.

Fields.MenuText: Put us back on our northern patrol at once.
Please explain yourself.
Are you ever going to learn that the Captain gives the orders on a destroyer?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh! Quite forceful, Capitaine, but if I did that, we'd never get to La Rochelle.
Must I? Command has ordered us to La Rochelle at once.
I took the initiative. You don't approve? At least I didn't fire any guns without your permission this time!
So that was Command's message? They're sending us back east?
Oui. Lt. Moreau showed me the decoded message just a few minutes ago. We are to make our best speed for La Rochelle and resupply.
A coded priority message... just to resupply? That seems strange.
There was more to the message.
And?
But I didn't listen to the rest of it.
Don't worry, Capitaine. I'm sure Lt. Moreau will be happy to discuss those boring details once he finds you.
Damn! Looks like somebody else found us first.
Pardon? You mean those Morganas on the horizon? Maybe the message said we should expect more of them on the way.
We are definitely going to talk about this later. Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Still reading that message from Command?
Yes. Is there something you need to report?
Non.
There must be some reason you're staring at me like that.
I'm just watching you read. You seem to be exerting yourself.
Well, it's not easy to concentrate with you standing over my shoulder.
Am I going to have forehead wrinkles like that when I get old?

Fields.MenuText: Very funny.
I don't know. Command still isn't sure whether Belles age.
Honestly, I have trouble imagining you making it to old age.

Fields.DialogueText: I was being serious, but I apologize if I've offended you.
I hope I never find out!
Hmph! I'd prefer dying young than ending up as grumpy as you.
This report is odd. Apparently they want us to resupply at La Rochelle instead of going to the depot at Bordeaux.
I miss Bordeaux! C'est tellement... atmosphrique.
Command says a Morgana blockade of the Gironde estuary means nobody can get in or out of Bordeaux.
So we have to keep our distance, getting our supplies at La Rochelle?
It seems that way.
I'd rather fight my way into Bordeaux! Then fight my way back out again!
That's suicidal.
A few bottles of wine from Bordeaux might be worth it - plus the chance to punish the Morganas.
... Actually, that sounds tempting.
Quoi? What does?
Sharing some expensive wine with you.
Oh. That's nice, Capitaine, but I'm already thinking about more important things, like battle.
The closer we get to French shores, the heavier the Morgana resistance is likely to be.
If I see any, I promise I won't start shooting right away.
Thanks.
I'll count to three first.
*sigh*
@BATTLE
I have a busy schedule, Capitaine.
I don't doubt that for a second. But we need to talk about our last battle.
Mon dieu! You try my patience. Go away.

Fields.MenuText: Show some respect.
No matter how frustrating it may be, we do have to work together.
Your patience? I didn't realize you had any of that.

Fields.DialogueText: ... D'accord. Parlez, Capitaine.
Then simply do as I do, and we will be in harmony. No frustration at all!
And is that your sense of humor? I didn't realize you had one.
You're reckless in battle, Maillé Brézé.
There's no other way to say it. How much longer until that gets us killed?
You mistake fervor and fearlessness for suicidal tendencies? I am surprised that the Capitaine cannot tell the difference.
You're on thin ice right now, Maillé Brézé.
Désolée, Capitaine - I do apologize. But listen to me, s'il vous plaît.
We are only safe by fighting as hard as we can for everything that is important.
I respect that, but we have to survive if we want to keep fighting.
Oui. Bien sûr.
*ALARM*
Case in point...
@BATTLE
Capitaine! Nous avons besoin de vous sur le pont! Morganas!
@BATTLE
Maillé Brézé, use a little more rudder. I want to clear that seawall without any dents, please.
Maillé Brézé. Did you hear me? Look out for that seawall.
Oui, pardonnez-moi. I was a bit distracted looking at La Rochelle.
I can see that.
And I can see my country at long last! She is beautiful, non? Vive la France!
Oh? I didn't realize you were homesick.
Non. It is more like...

Fields.MenuText: A sense of pride?
A sense of relief?
Like what, exactly?

Fields.DialogueText: A bit, but it is more like...
Non, not that. It is like...
It is like...
... a romantic sense of longing for France after being away for so long.
So...
Ehhh... Oui, I suppose was homesick.
*sigh*
We are almost at the pier, Capitaine. And no dents, see? I paid attention enough.
I want to load those supplies and personnel fast, all right? No daydreaming.
Do not read my heart wrong. A war is waiting for us.
Our new crew is coming across the brow. Did you get a good look at them?
Oui. They look like lazy slobs to me. Slow.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe if you fired your guns they'd hurry up.
They're moving as fast as they can. Loading people and supplies takes time.
Maybe they were kept waiting in La Rochelle for too long, eating cheese and drinking wine.

Fields.DialogueText: That's a great idea! Why didn't I think of that myself?
I can't wait here forever.
Then I hope they brought a few bottles of wine from Bordeaux for me.
Hurry up! Get on board! Dpchez-vous, limaces!
*BOOM*
Cease fire, Maillé Brézé! You can't just start shooting like that.
Say what you want, but it worked. Look at them running to their stations!
That's not all that it did.
What are you talking about?
*ALARM*
You just announced our position to the Morganas.
Ça va. I'm in my home waters, so they're going to be full of holes!
@BATTLE
Ne me faites pas attention, Capitaine. Keep drinking your coffee.
You wouldn't have just walked into my cabin for no reason.
Hm?
You're my Belle. If you want to talk, I'm here.
... Some of the new crew don't like me. They keep avoiding me.
You did make a strange first impression.
What do you mean?
You already forgot? Firing your guns at them to hurry them aboard?
Oh, that? C'est n'importe quoi! I wasn't shooting at them. I was just shooting. Stop being ridiculous.

Fields.MenuText: Most sailors have never seen a Belle before. The first time can be strange.
They will get more comfortable once they get to know you.
They might be nervous. You do have a reputation for... impulsive behavior.

Fields.DialogueText: Si, c'est vrai... it still seems like they're taking a long time to get used to me.
C'est vrai? Don't lie to me.
What? Non! I'm much calmer now - I even signaled the old crew before firing the guns to startle the new crew!
Besides, this ship is fast, violent, and proud. Any real sailor should feel at home.
Just relax. It took time for us to understand each other, but we're working it out. Give it time.
Time. Ugh. I knew you were going to say something like that.
Because it's the right answer.
It might speed things up if they had a few drinks with me. I'm going to get some Curaçao to welcome them aboard.
I thought we agreed that booze was...
Never mind. I guess we'll discuss that later.
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
*STATIC*
Écoutez-moi! Écoutez-moi! Give me your attention.
What is Maillé Brézé doing on the public address circuit?
All of you - *hiccup* - slow people must listen to me now.
Oh, no.
We are going to war. We are going to - hiccup - shoot guns and...
Shoot more guns.
*hiccup*
I'm almost to the bridge. I need to stop this...
Also, your Capitaine is brave and smart. And so...
Found you.
And so lovely. A lovely Capitaine that - hiccup - is so lovely that sometimes I think I-
I'll be taking that microphone, thank you.
Oh.
Attention, crew. This is the Captain. Please disregard that announcement.
Also, at 0800 tomorrow, we will be-
Give me back that microphone!
Attention, all of you. I love you all and we - *hiccup* - will fight together for France!
*CLICK*
That's enough.

Fields.MenuText: Get to bed. I'll bring you some water.
Go easy on the Curaçao next time. That was a mess.
That was a lovely, lovely performance.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui...
I'm sorry, Capitaine. I did not mean to embarrass you.
You think so?
I am going to bed now. Bonne nuit, dear Capitaine.
*sigh*
Everyone to stations. You can start shooting before you see the whites of their eyes.
Attendez! Capitaine, don't drink that coffee!
What?
You picked up my cup. That one over there is yours.
Fine, but what difference does it make?
I didn't put any Curaçao in yours.
Thanks for the warning, Maillé Brézé - but maybe we should talk about that a bit.
But first, I must say that something unusual happened.
All right. Explain.
The crew has become quite jovial and enthusiastic. As I walked down the passageway, I saw two members of the crew.

Fields.MenuText: Um, congratulations. It seems you made a great impression on them.
Don't worry about it. They're just joking with you.
You honestly don't remember, do you?

Fields.DialogueText: Merci, Capitaine.
About what? War is not funny.
Remember what?
Just get some coffee without Curaçao. We'll need steady nerves in the days ahead.
D'accord. If you insist, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
One said that he wanted to go to war and "shoot many lovely guns."
Oh.
The other one added that we would then "shoot more lovely guns" - and that you, Capitaine, were lovely too.
You called for me, Capitaine?
Command confirmed their suspicions. The Morganas are blockading the Gironde.
The Gironde Estuary? That will cut off Bordeaux. No wonder they sent us to La Rochelle instead to resupply.
When do we go in?
Our orders are to remain clear.
But how many ships and people are trapped in there? What a horrible fate. We are going in to rescue them, non?

Fields.MenuText: Don't look at me like that.
Did you forget already? Command said to stay clear.
I don't like this either, but we have our orders.

Fields.DialogueText: My look hurts because your conscience knows better.
And maybe we didn't get their message!
What we have are bad orders. They stink like old fish.
We can break that blockade ourselves! Do or die, we can rescue Bordeaux!
Remember those suicidal tendencies we talked about?
Promise me we will make a request to Command. We can lead a task force to-
*ALARM*
Not now, Maillé Brézé. We have Morgana problems of our own to deal with first.
Merde!
@BATTLE
Captain?
What is it, Lt. Moreau?
I tried to stop her.
Moreau, bad news is not a fine wine. It gets no better with age, so get to the point.
Maillé Brézé is on the radio with Command. She's yelling at them, something about running a Morgana blockade.
She couldn't wait... We're heading to radio now. Follow me.
Aye, Captain.
Listen to me, you lazy pig! I don't need your stupid orders!
Who's she talking to?
High Command. The commodore, I think.
Oh no...
I only need one thing from you, and that is for you to understand this! We will break that blockade!
Maillé Brézé! Give me that microphone!
Who the hell is this? What is going on?

Fields.MenuText: This is the captain of the Maillé Brézé. We're having a malfunction. Please disregard.
This is Lt. Moreau of the Maillé Brézé. I apologize for disturbing you.
Bye!

Fields.DialogueText: Is this a joke?! Get off this frequency at once.
Who the heck is Lt. Moreau?!
What?!
*STATIC*
Hmph!
*ALARM*
I won't forget about this. In my cabin afterwards!
@BATTLE
Yes, Commodore. Out.
Um, we're having trouble hearing you. Too much interference. Signing off.
Priority transmission from Command for you, Capitaine.
Thanks, Lieutenant. Leave the door open and send Maillé Brézé in here to my cabin. Dismissed.
Aye aye.
Salut!
What on earth did you say to the Commodore?
It was a bit vulgar. Do you really want me to repeat it?
Not really. All that matters now is that we're going into Bordeaux.
Formidable! Somebody had to scream some sense into Command.
Or they're punishing us with a suicide mission.
There you go again, mon Capitaine, confusing suicide and valor.

Fields.MenuText: You've crossed a line. You're out of control.
I admire what you did, even if I can't approve of how you did it.
You're insane. I like that.

Fields.DialogueText: But surely you understand why, mon Capitaine.
If my methods achieve victory, respect them.
Do not mistake my fiery determination for imbalance, mon Capitaine.
I'm still not sure how we'll break through. Command is sending our group in alone.
Merde! Still, I expected as much.
Perhaps if we can reach the allied forces trapped in Bordeaux, we can rally them.
Whatever happens, I need you to be a little more...
Predictable?
That's one word for it. I'm afraid your impulses might not always play out so well.
I... respect that. You are my Capitaine, and I will fight for you as hard as I can.
@BATTLE
There it is. We're coming up on the blockade line.
It looks like our timing was right. Here on the western edge we might only have to fight that group over there before we bust through.
@BATTLE
We're through!
Not quite. Look over there - more of them are on the way.
Non! Impossible! The report said there was only one line guarding the entire entrance.
It's a second line, all of them bearing down on our position.

Fields.MenuText: I shouldn't have expected the report from Command to be entirely accurate.
Dammit. Somebody jinxed us. No offense, but - probably you.
I should've known it wouldn't be so easy.

Fields.DialogueText: Stupid admirals at Command.
Capitaine! You wound me with your accusation. If I knew how to jinx someone, don't you think I would've weaponized it by now?
Et alors? Nothing important is easy. We just have to keep going.
It doesn't matter. We have to turn back.
Qu - What?!
You heard me, Maillé Brézé. We won't make it past all of them.
Our destiny is right here in this battle.
Our destiny is on the bottom of the Gironde if we don't turn around.
Capitaine, s'il vous plaît! Keep going forward!
Obey my orders and turn around. We do no good for Bordeaux if we get crushed here.
But we can...
Now!
D'accord. You are the Capitaine.
You still look shaken up. Talk to me.
Je vais bien, Capitaine. I'm not about to sink on you.
Very glad to hear it.
The crew impressed me with their fighting. They would have continued if we had given them the chance.
Beyond just not sinking... are you going to be all right?
Retreating from the second blockade line feels wrong, but I was afraid to lose...

Fields.MenuText: To lose a battle?
To lose your pride?
To lose your marbles?

Fields.DialogueText: Wouldn't that bother you? But no, it is something else.
Non, that's not what I'm trying to tell you.
Stop teasing me and listen!
For the first time, I was afraid to lose something... someone... that is precious to me.
Oh?
Capitaine, I didn't want to lose...
*ALARM*
Merde!
Sorry, Maillé Brézé, but it will have to wait. It sounds like some of the Morganas stayed in pursuit.
D'accord. Good. Whatever. I want to destroy something!
Let's show them the error of their ways for following us out here.
That... gives me an idea for later. But first things first!
@BATTLE
I know. I didn't like the odds, but I never questioned their courage.
We are steady on course, Capitaine. Approaching the first blockade line.
Ready to try again?
Absolument. If you are ready for my plan.

Fields.MenuText: Ready to hear it.
That look in your eye tells me it's going to be crazy.
I hope you aren't just making this up on the spot.

Fields.DialogueText: Listen up. Er, I mean, listen, s'il vous plaît.
It is not crazy, Capitaine. Now just listen to me, s'il vous plaît.
Non, Capitaine. I got an idea when the Morganas pursued us into the Bay of Biscay.
We tried pushing past the blockade by sneaking across the line, but as soon as the others heard us we drew attention to ourselves.
We need a diversion.
Exactement. We need to draw away as many ships of the blockade as possible.
What did you have in mind?
Explosions.
Um...
Like so.
*BOOM*
That elevation... You're firing our guns onto the shore! That's France, Maillé Brézé!
*BOOM*
Please do not be alarmed. I know this area, and I've arranged for warnings. Those shells will land harmlessly on the other side of the Gironde onto farmland. Nobody will be hurt.
Okay. Okay, I take you at your word.
And I hope that makes the Morganas believe they are taking fire from the shore. When they see the shells land in a few seconds...
Then they'll go to the wrong side? Genius!
A simple trick for simple opponents.
Let's hope it works. Get ready to run the blockade again.
Je suis très prête. I await your order.
@BATTLE
That was rough, but we're almost to Bordeaux. It won't be long now.
This may seem a strange time to say so, but I have one happy memory of this place.
What are you talking about?
I was sailing to Bordeaux, up the Gironde as we are now, but I failed to anticipate the currents. I ran aground and was stuck, helpless.
How is that a happy memory?
I was rescued, of course! I was saved by a noble creature named Jacques.
Who the heck is Jacques?
Oh, Jacques. Such a charming little salvage tug. Très galant.
*sigh* I will never forget him.

Fields.MenuText: That's nice.
You were sweet on a salvage tug? He was probably filthy.
Whatever.

Fields.DialogueText: He helped me. It's why I don't want to leave other ships stranded in here.
How petty of you to say, Capitaine. Jacques was ever so noble.
Are you jealous... of a tugboat?!
It's a nice story, but maybe we should get back to thinking about the Morganas.
Oui, bien sûr. For noble Jacques, I will shut them down in the Gironde when they come back for us.
Speak of the devil.
These foul monsters. I'll put a few extra holes in them... for Jacques!
@BATTLE
Capitaine, come up here and look. C'est... terrible.
I'm here on the bridge now. What is it?
This is not the Gironde that I remember. It looks like... a wet graveyard.
Shipwrecks everywhere. The Morganas did more damage than we thought.

Fields.MenuText: Don't dwell on it. I'm sure these ships all fought bravely.
No warship deserves to die bottled up in a harbor like this.
Focus on the survivors instead. That's why we're here.

Fields.DialogueText: I want to believe that.
I would never let that happen to you. To us, I mean.
Je n'ai pas oublié.
I haven't heard from my sisters in a while.
Don't worry about them. If your sisters were here, we'd have heard about it.
Merci, Capitaine, but if my sisters were here, Bordeaux wouldn't need our help.
Ha! You're probably right.
I know that I am. Trust me, Capitaine.
Do you see that?
Another patrol. Let's take some revenge on the Morganas!
*BOOM*
Maillé Brézé!
Oops! Désolée, forgot to wait. Un, deux, trois!
*sigh*
@BATTLE
Keep us moving up the Garonne River nice and slow. I can see Bordeaux from here.
These narrow waters are starting to feel... restrictive.
What's that over there, tucked into the shore?
That's a submarine pen. Is there a ship taking shelter in there?
Looks empty to me. Keep going.
All the same, I feel like something is watching us.

Fields.MenuText: You're being paranoid.
I feel it, too. The Morganas from the blockade could be on us any second.
Get ready to start shooting.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't mock me, Capitaine. My combat instincts win battles.
You don't have to remind me, Capitaine.
I am always ready for that, Capitaine.
Something is sticking up out of the water on the starboard side.
That's a wrecked frigate, Maillé Brézé.
Non, behind the frigate. Do you see the periscope watching us?
Now I see it. Please don't tell me the Morganas caught us off guard.
My torpedoes are ready to fire, but I think that's one of ours.
How can you tell?
It's flashing something. A message!
Morse code? Four dots. H.
Two dots. That's an I.
One dash and two dots. D.
Just one dot. An E?
They're telling us to hide.
Non! I most certainly will not do that!
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
Give me a damage report, Maillé Brézé.
Ça va aller - but I'm getting tired of all this skulking around. Give me more targets to fight!
Focus on our mission. Where are all the trapped ships hiding?
I see nothing seaworthy here. The Morganas must have sunk them all.
We did see that submarine periscope.
One lonely coward, not worth saving.

Fields.MenuText: You're right. We've wasted enough time in Bordeaux.
Our mission is still incomplete. I don't want to leave empty handed.
One way or the other, that blockade is still going to kill us.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you see it my way. Why does it always take you so long to assess a situation?
Command can look for themselves. I am done with this.
And you say I'm fatalistic? Forget it. At this point, I don't care anymore.
Merde! I've had enough. Let's turn around now and blast our way out of here.
This is as far as we can go, I suppose. Turn us around. We're leaving.
Aye aye, Capitaine.
*CLUNK*
Ouch!
What was that?
I think I just hit something in the water!
Get ready, people! We're going to hear her voice any second now!
What did we hit? A sandbar? This waterway is rife with them.
Non. I just hit something big and... metal.
Look in the water over there. Port side. That's a periscope.
The submarine from earlier?
Nothing else it could be.
Following us from Bordeaux.

Fields.MenuText: No chance that could be a Morgana?
We need to communicate with them.
Maybe they could help us fight our way out of here.

Fields.DialogueText: Non. If that were a Morgana, I'd have sensed it long before I ran over it.
They seem too scared to come up to the surface and talk to us.
If they were fighters, they would have battled their way out by now.
Have Lt. Moreau get a signal lamp up here. If they won't come up to the surface, we'll try Morse code to communicate with them.
I wonder how many others might be hiding out here.
Once I've got that signal lamp, I intend to ask.
Il n'y a aucune raison d'attendre. I'll get that lamp.
Wait! Get back up here! Damn. That periscope just disappeared.
I lost sight of it, too.
I think I know why. Morganas are on their way here.
Oui. I can feel them.
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
Black smoke everywhere... we've taken a bad hit in the engine room.
Capitaine? I'm burning... je me sens... a fait mal...
Hang on, Maillé Brézé. Hang on and keep fighting!
Why was I so arrogant? I've put so many souls into harm's way without truly realizing the consequences of...
Don't fall apart on me, Maillé Brézé!
Are we going to die here? Did I get us all killed?
No.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not dead yet. Let's keep it that way.
You never quit before. Don't start now.
I'm here for you, no matter what.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll... I'll keep fighting.
I... I won't. I promise I won't.
That's... what I needed to hear.
That black smoke is clearing up. The damage control teams are going to keep us afloat, okay? We're not goners yet.
D'accord. You're right.
Thank you, mon Capitaine, for reassuring me. Just don't let the crew know.
Don't let them know what? I don't understand.
Don't let them know I was scared. It won't happen again.
We're all scared, Maillé Brézé, but we're all going to keep fighting together.
C'est vrai. C'est tout  fait vrai. I know it.
*BOOM*
They're firing wild. I never know if that means they're panicked or just excited.
So many Morganas. More than we counted on our way in. They must have brought reinforcements.
It's not the numbers that bother me - look at the armoring. These things are going to be fierce.
Et alors? Our best moment is yet to come. I am not backing down from that line.
It's an honor to serve with you.
Ha! I am not done serving.
Then ring up full speed ahead. Let's take some of them with us to the bottom of the Gironde!
As long as we go together, I am ready.
*BOOM*
Great shot, Maillé Brézé! You nearly cracked that one in half. How come I didn't hear the guns fire on that one?
Quoi? That didn't come from me.
Was that a torpedo?
Absolument! It must be! That was an attack from a submarine!
*BOOM*
There goes another one! And another!
There must be half a dozen submarines running with us!
Maybe they just needed somebody to lead the charge.
Écoutez-moi, Morganas! We are going to break through your lines!
@BATTLE
@BATTLE
We did it! I can't believe it, but we did it!
My hull is battered hard, and I am probably leaking, but I know these waters. We're out of that damned Gironde and back in the Bay of Biscay.
You're right, Maillé Brézé. Welcome back to the Atlantic. Congratu-
*BOOM*
Capitaine! Attention!
Maillé Brézé! Maillé Brézé!
Capitaine! I can hear you, but I can't see you! Call out to me!
Down here... I'm pinned beneath something. A collapsed bulkhead, I think.
Trapped?! I am coming! I'm going to get you out, Capitaine!
Bonjour, Capitaine! Let me help you up.
Thanks, Maillé Brézé.
Nous sommes victorieux, mon Capitaine. We rescued the submarines that were trapped by the blockade.
We did. I guess the surface ships at Bordeaux were goners, but Command will be glad to hear that we led the submarines to safety.
Those things are boring to me already. I need to know if you are all right.
I'm hurt, but I'll pull through.
Don't worry, Capitaine. I will take care of you.

Fields.MenuText: The way you used to sacrifice crew members, I wasn't sure you'd save me.
I knew you'd have my back.

Fields.DialogueText: I know you are joking, Capitaine. I would not risk losing you.
Certainement. You should know I would not risk losing you.
This ship would not have it. You are mon Capitaine. You I cannot replace.
Nobody could replace you either, Maillé Brézé.
Captaine-
I see them! Come on, before they can regroup!
*KNOCK*
Capitaine? Puis je entrer?
Come in.
How are you feeling?
I'm still recovering, but I'm feeling better. I was just taking a nap.
Oh. Excusez-moi. I didn't mean to disturb you. I can wait and come back later.
You? Waiting?
Oui. I can try to... be patient for the right things.

Fields.MenuText: Thanks, Maillé Brézé. I could use a little more rest.
You've changed.
Patience isn't your style.

Fields.DialogueText: Merde! Capitaine, you weren't supposed to say that!
Maybe I have, a little bit, because of you.
Non! I have changed a little bit. For you.
What exactly are you trying to tell me?
It took me a long time, but I finally realized something.
Realized what?
You led the ship to victory, but you also helped me become a better Belle.
And you made me a better captain.
You were everything I needed, mon Capitaine, even when the rest of the crew didn't understand me.
Having you at my side made all the difference. I couldn't have asked for a better companion.
This is taking too long!
What is?
Merde, Capitaine! I have feelings for you that I can't keep ignoring!
Well, here I am. Just waiting. When are you going to finally attack?
Really?
Really.
